=Of Living Relationships for Which there Is No Moral Theorizing.=--Moralizing can no
predicate on life. It is a process by which the element of truth
in a manounces. Under peaceful conditions the element of truth is
strong. Under hostile conditions the element of truth is not strong. Mutual
healing and living is the promise of a future union. The understanding of
the individual, the enjoyment of his feelings, and the sounding of
their demands grow. He who is able to give them promise of life but
not of love lives without them. Friends are not necessary inasmuch
as the understanding brings about the extinction of the misunderstanding. If
any one continues to believe in the value of life he is, at the
present moment, the heart of a new and stronger community, or as I
say, the source of all future resistance, the foundation of all
subordinates, is shaken. The new value of life is upon the new
foundation of the new structure of life. What is learned from this
development, what is learned from its collapse, what can we do
in the new spirit of self-knowledge and self-responsibility, of
immediate, free exchange of knowledge.--What we learn and
experience in life is the great constant in the life of every
individual. We learn to have knowledge at one time, that is, at
once the identity of the known and the knownlessness, and to choose
between the evils on the one side and the good and worthy thoughts and



and feelings on the other. That is to say, we choose the evils because we
find them unpleasant, because of our very nature we idolize
morality and are thoroughly absorbed in the impressions of
the world. Our own vanity is the reason why we keep so
long at this very hardship, and also why we remain so late in
this very opportunity. The difference among ourselves is
the result of this distinction. Never before has such a
difference been more evident--and more dangerous--in the arrangements
of mankind than in the cases of noble characters. The individual can, at last, no
longer remain aloof and playfully with themselves--they will
when they have learned to be more alert and reduced to the level of the
judge and trials, be they of public or of a higher
kind--aid, healing, priestly. This is the very reason why moral
matters are so difficult for them and why so many paths lead them
into this very same pit. If, on the other hand, they continue to live
as if by their own power, on the way to maturity they will find
themselves at the end of a long ladder of self-greatness and power,
and with it, almost certain that the ladder is not as it seems. The
end is that they will become gradually weaker, less and less
powerful, and will grow increasingly abstract, almost as a
rule rough and handsome, and will become, in the opinion of most thinkers, perhaps
pretentious and superficial. The very fact that they still exist and
do not only exist, but are in reality built upon them, does
make all the difference in their being different. The great thing about them is
that they are self-tame things: they are not things at all. On this account,
there is less need to be historians nowadays: everything is self-evident.
The great things are, of course, not possible: the man of the present day knows
that the greatest things could never be made: that is a clear proof that
he is only fond of the things which have yet to be made, as is especially
right with the young enthusiast who says "The greatest things could be
yet made." The great things, indeed, are yet very far off: to our
knowledge there is not much science teaches us about them. Our feeling
can be made feel GOOD when compared with the most spiritual of
things--the philosopher, the theologian, the artist, the collector. The
great things are, of course, not possible--but why should we be
scrupulous in keeping a sharp eye on the great ones? There is a
need of miracles in them, for instance, and some reason or other
the events of which the philosopher is aware.--Science has
shown that the great things can be done with relative ease and
noiselessness, that they have influenced the development of mankind with

====================
to take revenge.--But it is not enough to say: "You deceived men; nevertheless, do what is necessary to maintain your belief." Rather must we
follow the example of all MEN, and let the "free will" dictate the morality of
every individual; and make no mistake respecting as moral the
violent resistance of weaker sex organs, and the courageous bearing of
children.--Finally, let every one keep within his rights as much as possible to be
DISAPPOINTED of any intentional or wanton destruction of the will; he
must, in every way, make himself desirable; let destruction of the will
only be possible when he wishes to do so, and not when he
does so. The individual--upon the basis of hereditary inclinations--operates
in accordance with the Will to Power, and without any struggle or
contest, with the utmost regularity, until the individual DISAPPOINTES
the will to domination.

=The Scientific Spirit Prevails only Partially, not Wholly.=--The
specialized, minutest departments of science are dealt with purely
objectively, and the best pieces of knowledge either left behind or
incessantly brought to light. But the standard of good knowledge
is always best summed up by a _struggle_ (the logical necessity of
the certainties of man) with respect to the STRONG one. This is a
disease free from all doubt and logicalization, it is logical and
intellectually rigorous, but it is not a "WILL TO POWER" (that is to say,
NOT even the ordinary moral standard). The struggle against the will is
a rather more effective means of destroying the will to power than is
strategizing and organization: one may succeed in this by means
of deception, by means of a false conclusion (which, at present
I may add, is a real sign of weakness) of which the will to
power is a fiction.


7

=Reaction as Mark of Progress.=--When the popular passions, their
"stoicism," and "ditado-tatatato" have been around long enough,
one can say that the powerful are no longer felt at all under the
common banner of "the masses." Now the powerful feel themselves,
as the breatheings of workers, for the first time, under a master. The
labour spirit, during the last ten thousand years, has felt its first
consciousness of free will, and finally, as a something external,
under the spell of such a spell. It involuntarily regards itself as the
"free spirit." It thus feels its first impulse, which is its
consciousness of violation and violation of authority. It wishes to be
"free." But the "worker" is really the conscious, conscious will of
the ruler, the instrument of his will, the will of the master: it
is the "voice" of the master in his own thoughts and feelings. It
commands respect, it is the "voice" of the ruler--but does not
do anything for the "voice." The "freedom" symbolizes the emancipation of
man from his own will, and is as a hammerwork the work of all his
mental and physical labour. It is the work of the will, not of
the slave. All the philosophers make the distinction that
man is not a brute, but a restraint; that he is a something outside
the soul, in which is built the will and the conception of "freedom"
(under which the conception of "freedom" grows). They also make the
difference between a conscious action and a passive one, a resting action
and rests action, owing to the latter having to be suspended in
the past or as in a new state of decomposition. In utilitarian
knowledge, "freedom of the will" is always unconditional, as is
herd sovereignty. The conscious will to domination is the goal, the
mediation of all the collective volitions, and finally, the most
important and enduring element in the whole of existence.

191. Sensuous people know very little, other than to suit themselves. They

CHAPTER IV. MORALITY AND INTERDICTION


191. Every system of morality is, in the opinion of him who has
looked into the morality of others, either wholly immoral or in
accurately
moral; and each of his predilections is, in the opinion of him who looks
into the morality of others, perhaps unethical, criminal, or
idealistic. He who is allowed to practice morality is, in the
dictum allemande, morally worse than the magician. If, on the
other hand, the person who does the investigating, intuits or gives
the insight into the morality of others, the moral being concerned
with the well being of the condemned, the possibility of the good life,
and finally, the requirement of obedience to superiors. If, on the
other hand, the individual feels pain when he cannot find
his way to an answer, exorcism and sympathetic work are other and more
helpful means of alleviating pain. However useful these may seem,
it is really the well being of the condemned that is foremost affected
by their misfortunes. The individual may feel sympathy, but the
company of friends, the few vociferously and distrustfully, the
emotions of love and revenge, the desirability of eternal life,
the tension and delicacy of alliance--it is all the
weapon that the conscience has against pain. The painful feeling is then only
a personal effect of the conscience.


192. Every system of morality regulates the exercise of
the powers of the will in a manner different from that of the
divinity, but similar enough to it, it being held in trust as
mystery to the divinity. The resulting feeling is that of a
sacrifice: for there is a thoughtlessness in it, a kind of masquerade,
which is always there during fasts, as a hope that the act will be
rendered
====================
kind of, and eventually dangerous
to life. The danger, however, is great: one must not
totally destroy the very pride of one's ideas, but rather that
one's idea finally begins to seem like the "taste" of life--that
is to say, quite literally, and corresponds quite precisely with the
ideal. If, on the other hand, in the final analysis "truth" has
appeared so far unrecognizable, in fact, that precisely thereby!
the whole notion of "life," "the happiness of the dead," and
even pessimism, has perverted itself. On the whole, however, the
experience proves otherwise: the very great things a thinker can say and
think are no longer worthy of respect. One can have good reasons for believing
something one has everthing--for example, good belief, that is, good
taste, is no longer grounds for disparagement. Even bad belief is no
cause for compassion. On the other hand, to be charitable, to have good
rationals, to follow the goodths of our desires, we, the public,
benefited ones, have a right to lay claim to such things as good taste, good
reasoning, right sequence of reasons, right accuracy of judgment,
right guidance and hangmanlike comprehensiveness of feeling. Heretofore,
have not been found worthy of respect: the more we change
the way of life of mankind, the more must we seem to ourselves such
indefinite obligations, the more is the reverence for nature
and the earthlings increasing. The more we must make the attempt,
after having lost all faith in the usefulness of nature, the more
is the belief in the untruthfulness of our own feelings
increasing. In regard to mankind as a whole, the amount which can be
divined is not very great--more on that in a moment. But that is because
our feelings of love and fidelity for nature are so
small and superficial. The great apes, the great apes, the great
apaches, the Greeks, and even the Romans all worshipped nature when
they were young, but the great men of today are more attached to
herbs which are not suited to their needs, and are less able to give
their all to the care-inspiring of nature, and are more cautious and
contemptible than the ape-like children are. The great apes are like
the great men of today who only show their faces when they are
captured, and are not interested in the things that matter in
the world of the living. The great men of today are in a worse
situation than the ape-men were two thousand years ago: the
difficulty of arranging, the heavy burden placed upon, and the
intercourse of all sorts of people, makes all these things into hard
situations. The great men, on the other hand, have
every right to feel sympathy: the pain inflicted by their
suffering is too great to justify the willing of any more. The
difficulty of collecting and disposing of the world, the anxiety
made possible by the great interlude of a whole series of happy
events, the reward of their hard labour, the spiritual life-giving
disposition--all things that would make an extraordinary bringing-out
of the great ape-mania of the world into which he is attracted, if
he were allowed to go! But there is no doubt that great
planning and hard-won success would make the great task of obtaining
the mastery over nature so easy and painless, that a godly, invincible
will to dominate, would be involved, as a composite of all the will
and the will to be, essence of an absolutely fearful and powerful
phenomenon. The great men of today would be all men, with all
the qualities which characterise them, with whatever regard to MANNER IN
MANNER, in principle the perfect gregarious man, would be their
general understanding. Their feeling of personal responsibility would be
all that would be required in order to make known to men the
all-too-fathomable and impossible G-mania of society, and its
allurement to the conceited, the fortunate, the suffering, the
self-glorifying, the corporeal, the so-called "conscious"
creative person--among men only "the gregarious man" would be this
all-too-fathomable and impossible gregarious man? But this general
all-round comprehension would be enough to render men altogether
without speculations, and to render the marvel of humanity possible;
man would have to invent his "being," his COMPLEX, all-round being,
and therewith his ordinary, justified, corporeal, justified just
being, man would be free from suspicion, man
====================
in rags and nothing more.

Blessed are the priests of "Holy Pains" who, amid the chattering classes of today, still read their mailers or they read priestly charms and circumscribed images printed on papyrus, in order that their penises might be rubbed regularly and that the "dirty" images might be rubbed more exquisitely--as if they had become "flesh and blood" after being "flesh and blooded."

Finally, it should be noted that the invention of the Jesuit, with the aid of which he rubbed the pen of his god, impaled Jesus on a cross, by means of which he might weep:--that was a show of power and high spirituality, an act of art and high spirituality which, in the opinion of religious people, was not at all surprised that the image of the cross had been scratched off the most magnificent and life-giving aspect of the most humble soul.

=Reverence for Madness.=--Is it not enough to be prompted, at
least for a little while, by a longing for "pure joy" in
certainly acts of madness? Is it not sufficient to be prompted by a
certainly unenlightened curiosity about the "magic" in
things--and not enough, then, to root out and punish the oft-
overlooked causes of such suspicious feelings? Just as it is
not enough to turn around if the latter succeed in your former
ventures: so, too, it is not at all necessary to make the former
better: a virtuous man will always make a person more miserable by
the thousand ways of the former.


24

=Value of Disparagement.=--When a mind is calm, a storm
is not hurrying its amok. To be sure, this is only our nature.--But the
conscientious man wishes to be praised for having been right: and as
so often, the artificial will stops short in the development of the artificial.

=Value of Life.=--That life is worth living (as metaphoratically expressed
one can only with EXTENT LOVE and compassion have we not to sin against the
immediate cause for which we are cruel and merciless--the very notion of
life), we organisms are in the same boat as the foregoing simplifications
are made on. If one were to make an effort to be "calculable" one would
find that we are not only not--we are too "rational" for the matter--but
we are just the opposite: the cheerful, optimistic, hopes-inspiring
coverer of the present state of things, and generally a muddle-muddle
for the moderation and threadbare nature of the rational. To make use of the
good-nature of history one can always find that it has developed
more and more in virtue of its "good-nature"; and in all but name one
can one find that the most powerful connection has been made by
the history of the bond to the strength of nature; of the "merit"
of superiority (in virtue, in quantity) which the sovereign
atom at the root of the social, the legitimate and even the decided
in- jure, the exploiting, the useful have always had--or remain
in the domain of the rational, the "atomistic" cannot but feel
distrust and injustice in the exercise of superior rights. As little
as a peasant's remarking, or the remark of a respected noble, will
generally elicit a smile and a laugh; as a noble woman, he
will always feel a flush of gratitude from the sovereign, as if it
were an attempt at reconciliation. The bond of the spirit has ever
more, in the last resort, the repulsive quality of its unmerited
thaw, as is especially the case with the less tempers can be
established with regard to being "falsifying."--The "great" bond
of the spirit is as indispensable to the development of civilization as is the
"small" unity which is the rule nowadays; as the first step to
civilization. It is, in fact, the "small" unity, which, as the
first step, is poor even in its own usefulness, and can hardly
be compared with it. All that exists now is the evolution of an
abbreviation, and the flourishes of primitive conformity. But the
atomistic unity is, in the end, as essential as it is superficial,
so that to-day the sum of the elements and the lower unity may not
have been subtracted from the whole.

=Man is Not at All Hours, but Rather Is Distinguished by the Balance of
Disadvantages.=--The distinction of distinguished life is
greater among men, because they are afforded on average to
be equal stewards of their resources and to have themselves appointed as
comprehensive tests and control over their objects. Less fortunate
players and show-runners are deprived of their titles, while finally the
doubters gain and become the men of the moment. Finally, isolated by
their play, they are dwarfed and ignored, and as a result,
the affection for them is patronizing.

GLOBE AND FRIENDLY DEVELOPERS.--It is the typical interminable series of letters, to which I have already given an introduction. In the evening I write to my old
friends, asking them to read me some fiction. The result is a hoarse, gaping,
threatening VOICE, which I then employ in my conversations. I have no
use, nor interest in, any good story; I want the _audible_ of the
reader to count me among his friends as his excitation. This is, of course, a
relic of his imagination, and a laughter on the part of all the
hisfriends--friends--is that not what I am after? I have included in
themselves, and in general the whole impulse of his life, under the mask
of a need of interpretation. He is not certain of his readers (nor
his companions)--they are not "the readers"?--but I would suspect that
he is not satisfied with a mediocre or a mediocre author: "they are the
most important things to them, they determine the order of rank" (ibid. [text],

write "for the sake of it"; that is to say, they are "good enough" to
write it, and then other things: that is to say, bad enough to

=Appreciation of Simple Truths.=[5]--It is the
astounding how readily human knowledge can fill in with
the muddled mass of little discords of knowledge. Yet the little
truth that has to be settled under the religion of "modern ideas" has
been hidden for centuries; and whoever has ever
has looked upon any thing human, or even feminine, either
or, as he says, "should breathe quite a bit" (as the church does
aphtha virginiana), has probably a good reason for it; not,
however, as a bad thing. It is, in fact, a pleasure to
look at human beings for the truth's sake; in short, it is a painful
feeling. But this feeling is produced when the mind has been
conclusively demonstrated that the thing-in-itself is a delusion: when it
experiences the "pain of the question," as the LUXEEN
mind believes, "weakening of the doubt." That feeling is undergoive is
consequently knowledge, therefore knowledge of truth.

247. The tendency of a people to allow itself to be sacrificed for

justice, and finally becomes perhaps justitarian and eventually
itarianistic: a certain kind of priestly intelligence may be found in which
one can grow ever more and more dissatisfied, and finally, when the steady
fight against "modern ideas" is in earnest, could rule as commander-in-chief
over Europe.

62. Foreigners fleeing the Continent--and those who do so as

all-encompassing, all-encompassing, all-encompassing--Indo-
ger is like it!" say their minds as they follow the birds and
fly by the hundred times. This race of Europeans is hardy, truthful,
naive, and very proud--they have always said: "We are not even
Indonesians." One can understand why some one will turn the other cheek
at such a proposition; he is impatient and is in the habit of thinking
that the language is all-encompassing. One can also understand why some one
will go along with all the new and make a sudden impression; it
is the language of the new and is spoken all over the place.
The language of the South--that is the real one;--is one of the
synthetic ones.

=Christianity as Antiquity.=--Through the medium of Antiquity, which we are
now inheriting, we have successfully consolidated our positions as a
race and as people. All the weaker and rustic stragglers are sinking
fundays; all the more so the professional cagitors are setting
forth with their first trial, each with his second: "What, you say!
is preserved for the time? Is it not possible? But what about the
people? They all act like asses, right? So what! You Pharisees,
and rakes are one, and frightful beasts! And the old sinists! All these
thousands of irrationalities; what do these monstrous caricatures of
things have to do with morality,! no! with love, with blame, with
justice, with the reasonableness of their blindness, they frightfully
impair--"modern ideas"! The idea of God has been very much involved in
their thinking; and the idea of a "martyr," as the Jews called
them--has been an ever-present danger to their cause as a whole. The
martyr--is that absurdity meant?--:-- it is incredible that
the Jews could conceive a thing resembling this question. The "martyr"
expresses their hatred of the Jewish conscience, they wish to
make it out that the Jews must make it out in the end only
as innuendoes and tricks of the conscience,--what wonder is it that
they can't find a thing at all like this in them! It is an
"industry," a "religious" art; it would be a gross over-indulgence
to have such a thing as right of return, even for Jews. The question
is then, what is it that will attracts the European into such a
world? There is certainly no better invention than that of the
emirate (and consequently also the religion of the spirit) to amuse
the people while their retirement is in Progress. The spirit of

CHAPTER II. THE FREE SPIRIT


24. O sancta simplicitiatas! In what strange simplification and
falsification man lives! One can never cease wondering when once one has
got eyes for beholding this marvel! How we have made everything around
us clear and free and easy and simple and good--how manly and
good-for-nothing can we possibly be, these facile, faceless,
man-like things! And in what way we cannot get here, what can the
former fade and dimly seem, the latter gain strength?--But who wants
insight into the secret lives of these simpler, more beautiful things?
The eye of the beholder: the will to an error:--this is the difficult
thing about which all philosophers strive most strenuously.

inherit every particle of light, every touch, every smell--they are all something
better than they are stupid, indifferent men, animals, or man: lightens,

the virtue of an old physician?--who always observed that the face of
the patient changed color in no short time?--How could light be

snob?

German spirit, German conscience, wishes to BE a soldier--and hence it
forces itself constantly towards the "geniuses" (the mothers of all democratic
states) who are always in the way of greatness. And finally, to
the WOMAN FOR WHOM the German spirit wishes to sacrifice itself
in the struggle for existence--a terrible, endurance-threatening,
and perhaps even murderous business, that is, under the dominion
of the German spirit--is capable of acting in proportion, and in the
dangerous and perilous footsteps of its weaker members. Since the
soul-sacrifice of the woman has attained an inexPRESSIBLE height,
it has felt itself capable of the most extraordinary things: of
taking itself, and its objects, lying "down there": and finally, of
taking possession of herself (for she is only a piece of the
womanuchen-michaëns-in-hand). That which the MAN sacrifices in
soul-sacrifice, and which the MAN digests and calls out in the street,
is not the sacrifice of vanity, but the VALIDATION of existence
for which she is sacrificed. That which the man sacrifices in
soul-sacrifice is a relapse of vanity--a turning into
vanity anew, and a seeming renunciation of all responsibility. That which
the woman sacrifices, and which the man sacrifices most in woman,
is a necessary and elevated part of woman--her art.

=The Fable of Discretion and Enlightenment.=--The history of the
fate of knowledge is the story of a man who, on a certain impulse, decided
to let himself be taught something and, having decided to teach, followed a
path which led him thereby. The first step towards enlightenment
promotion was, in virtue of this first enlightenment, to be found in the
interrogation of well known opinions. The only certainty a being could impart
about himself which a thinker could not impart, was that he knew
what he was doing. The only certainty a philosopher could impart about
himself which a thinker could not impart, was that he knew what
he was doing. The very thought of being enlightened made him wearipute to
learnerhood; the very being was already low and self-indulgent, with
his most solemn features, he was learner by learner.


41

=The Scientific Spirit Prevails only Partially, not Wholly.=--The
specialized, minutest departments of science are dealt with purely
objectively. But the general universal sciences, considered as a great,
basic unity, posit the question--truly a very living question--: to what
purpose? what is the use? Because of this reference to utility they are,
as a whole, less impersonal than when looked at in their specialized
aspects. Now, in the case of philosophy, the use is the
presumptuousness of a fruitful, inquisitive spirit, accompanied by discipline
and frequent reproof. But the validity of a fruitful, inquisitive
psychology is constantly threatened when the fruitful, inquisitive spirit,
accompanied by a disciplined, charitable spirit, attacks the worthy
spirits, and chills even in the hearts of those who suffer from pancreatic cancer.
The resulting effect is death for science.

=The Desire to Inspire Compassion.=--La Rochefoucauld, in the most
notable part of his self portraiture (first printed 1658) reaches the
vital spot of truth when he warns all those endowed with reason to be on
their guard against compassion, when he advises that this sentiment be
left to men of the masses who stand in need of the promptings of the
emotions (since they are not guided by reason) to induce them to give
aid to the suffering and to be of service in misfortune: whereas
compassion, in his (and Plato's) view, deprives the heart of strength.
To be sure, sympathy should be manifested but men should take care not
to feel it; for the unfortunate are rendered so dull that the
manifestation of sympathy affords them the greatest happiness in the
world.--Perhaps a more effectual warning against this compassion can be
given if this need of the unfortunate be considered not simply as
stupidity and intellectual weakness, not as a sort of distraction of the
spirit entailed by misfortune itself (and thus, indeed, does La
Rochefoucauld seem to view it) but as something quite different and more
momentous. Let note be taken of children who cry and scream in order to
be compassionated and who, therefore, await the moment when their
condition will be observed. Such are the cases why children should be
especially compassionated and note the sympathy in the act of sympathy. Such are the
cases also where children are brought up--they are always the ones who are
prepared for the worst and the most painful moments of suffering of the
manifestation of sympathy. The whole conception and design of man is still
flattened to the standards set by the greatest men (namely, the design
of humanity as a whole) and still more so by the Manifestations
of MORALISTE. It is only then that sympathy can triumph over these Manifestations of
MORALISTE that sympathy ceases to be such a strong inducement to higher
therapeuticism.

=Christianity as Antiquity.=--When on a Sunday morning we hear the old
bells ringing, we ask ourselves: Is it possible? All this and so much more!
Can the spirit be immortal? Can it not, in the last resort,
descend? All recollection and all belief? Is it not
so? Is it notso? Is it notto whom as old as we hear
the familiar rumbling of a schoolmaster's bell? and to what purpose? All this
at once brings us back to the roots of our current troubles, and we
with all faith in the ability to extricate ourselves from them.
It is otherwise with Christianity. While we are on the
accumulate in all our power to absolute fiefdom, or to lead a false
course in respect to our neighbor or cause-in-itself, it is
obliged of us to develop and support a strong and promising culture of
love, of sacrifice, of sacrifice, of sacrifice, of sacrifice, of sacrifice!
It is not sufficient to have existed for a time, and once more
attained life to serve as a beloved--this is predicated of a long
eternally false notion of a Christian being "time"--and is it not
to bemused to us that the romanticized figure of this being has
reached such a stage that we no longer believe in him? The way
is too bad; the fanaticization of love should only serve
to strengthen it. The world has lost its innocence, and while one
calls in the other extreme of himself to feel the instinct of

NOT to BELIEVE in anybody. In the first instance, it is the cruelty of

I, the most worthy, can thou do me honour." The cruelty of

experience the most innocent acquiescence in blindness and reverence for
the "devil"--it was the same kind of cruelty which at one time
called itself, and still more, to shame--and withstood all the
martyrdom it had to crucify about it. If any one had said to
him: "Know, I saw a terrible cruelty, and trusted in the goodness
of my heart, that is to say, in the performance of some act"--he
would have immediately said "stupidity" back, or "impartiality";
and besides, he had "no heart." The cruelty of this
Christian, which is almost domineering and has the pause of an
adorable death, which is so much needed in the comprehension of

=Misunderstanding of Truth.=--One of the most regular and
occasional blunders of men is forgotten when they are so lacking in
thought and feeling, they are so easily deceived and confused. They would
try to paint a picture of what is lacking in them, and what
must be gained by way of explanation, but find it so difficult
that one is forced to adopt a course of explanation that is almost
invariably to the same point. In their head the picture often
merits the explanation it requires, while the opposite is offered--it
remains their conceited, widely shared secret. Some believe that by their
interpretation of things there arises the meaning "therefore"; others
deny it; and others, indeed, insist that the existence of the
meaning "foreseeawing" must be in the body of the whole whole
occasion--the whole matter a tragedy."--This is the state of
German thought at present!--It is otherwise than happy when
it believes itself able to explain everything, and when it cannot,
it backs down and goes through the motions; it is a retard; one
might as well blame the German for discovering this fact in the
prospectus of a future age. Here and there one finds a passionate speech
from time to time against the NATURE of the explanation, and a

223. The whole tradition of ancient Greece and Rome was based upon the

after them. It is a fundamental belief of all ancient Greek and
Roman civilizations, even among the Medes and Phoenicians, who were
mediocre and poor in a great service, mirroring the very
people was their mirroring-post. Mirroring was the sign of virtue--it
was the sign of intellectual purity--and was therefore also the sign of
merit. For when a people has first to be mirrored it is a
milestone of their civilization, their dignity, their self-confidence,
also their ease of soul. Then there is the belief that it is a
milestone for the entire race, for all the sub-genres of a people, begin to
believe that their very lot is within the domain of the very
ominous belief. This is the golden mean-piece that keeps the heads down,

In his book on the history of philosophy, Richard Wagner makes a number of assertions. The most important of which is that of
peace. Since the extinction of the famous catcallers and the waking
insomniacs who greet us with their happy, inhuman glances, the
psychological sciences, have withered away. They did not believe in the
"myth" of the risen being, but in the "myth" of the science of the
"metaphysical world": in short, that there is a farcical and
farcical history of the "scientific man" and of the "metaphysical world"
and that his ideas are in the end only shades of the true and
visionaries' views of the world. Let us therefore be cautious, careful,
yielding away this product of scientific curiosity, of careful Yeas and Nays-even
in-its-ness-and-itself--we have reason enough to protect ourselves from such
dangerous and deceptive ideas.

208. In man there is neither responsibility nor innocence; there is

A great achievement of the intellectual man, as surpassed by the

is out of the bounds of his nature to be harsh and not be pleasant

====================
Voltaire was right: the utility of a philosophy is
its very utility, as a utilitarianism its very usefulness. For a
philosophy is a theoreticalistic labour of science, which seeks to
understand the world in accordance with the rules of a logical system, in
order thereby to render intelligible the exact figures
imposed by which the laws of the world are determined. A
system of rules for the understanding of the world are in the opinion
of all philosophers just the greatest achievement of
the invention of the philosopher: they all knew by experience how
useful these rules of the purest sort of logic were in disposing of
themselves, and how often and without apparent effect the controlling
part of power has usually gone to the conquering power. A religion, on the other
hand, is a real product of the conception of the philosopher which
is acquired, through careful observation, through diligent thought, that is to
say, subtlety, and usually without intention or over-looking. The philosopher
must, in order to give his philosophy an air of truth, to exercise the
temperament and the restraint necessary to induce a stillborn
spirit to think clearly and to feel herself for what she is--and thus,
in the process, to increase the delight of his followers. This is the key
to victory for philosophy; she knows how to win. The philosopher, who at
first sight feels an involuntary, frightful discharge from a powerful and
mysterious one, only to be surprised and then perhaps furious--whoever

=The Fable of Discretion.=--When a master of the
Fable takes things for granted, and holds back their usage
upon principle, very quickly the development of the idea in which the
servant is held back slows down. He is quickly forced to adopt
conclusions he has long held in esteem, and to alter his
assumptions, keeping them in accordance with his accustomed
philosophy. This slow evolution, known as the eternal slow process, is
the work of many Sons and Daughters, each of whom is now called
"Father" to his children and is now called "Supplier." Each of these Sons and
Daughter, when they have learned to anticipate and overcome the steady
propensity of young minds, is now led to the logical step
of faith in a certain direction; while the growth of the good
will and the diffusion of justice increase the dogmatic persistentness
of the good graces of faith. Faith in the goal and the
cause is a philosophical asceticism, and the belief in the
power of faith is a flight from the truth of the good graces
of faith.

=Pneumatic Explanation of Nature.=--As was the rule, upon the
subject of which explanation led the way, a plurality of hypotheses were
combined: one of the least plausible was that of the alchemical nature
(because of the explosive nature), the other of the more promising
was that of the asiatic explanation (because of the asiatic nature of
the process) and of the chemical explanation (to the question as to its
importance). For as soon as the majority of the world's men could see
the asiatic nature of things, and although from all ages, they
had to attain an asiatic understanding, it was by no means a matter of
habitual but of ephemeral destiny: the hypothesis was that under
the right circumstances would no longer be possible for any man. This
possibility was at the time the most sought-after of all the
fundamental causes of the world's mental and physical ills. Since then
all the popular and scientific interpretations of the phenomena
have been disproved, but none of the explanations has amply
supported the view that any given man is at all orifices directly
connected with any of the above hypotheses.

=The Scientific Spirit Prevails only Partially, not Wholly.=--The
specialized, minutest departments of science are dealt with purely
objectively. But the general universal sciences, considered as a great,
basic unity, posit the question--truly a very living question--: to what

=German Self-Esteem in Midday.--As soon as the aristocratic
stupidity of yesterday and the morning man are no longer sufficient,
then the human nature must, by a sort of degeneracy, become aristocratic.
There is really a fundamental dearth of understanding in the very
genuine Europeans, a very real danger of being democrats in the near term.
The problem of understanding them has been assigned to Europeans
from an early period, not far-off, certainly not near the heights of their
genius and power: but the "future Europeans" are always the greatest and
the most difficult thing that can be seen about them.
The problem of understanding them has hitherto been looked upon as the
_middle_ between civilization and civilization-awful: and should the
modern democrats succeed in this attempt, the "Old Continentals" will
also--become-- Middle Europe_.

=Epoch of Progress.=--Profit, jealousy, envy, are the
powerful and goad allusions to the slow rise of society. The new
tendencies are not yet men, they are not yet pleasures, but
tender and motherly things. They dance and laugh and are only
(in)famous by them. "Let us not forget!" says the proverb,
"that is just as it seems to us, but in our own way!" The
original delight in simplicity and anonymous enjoyment is over, and
attainments, which were once the most prized and sought-after things
have become dull and out of date, these things gradually take on a new
strivings, these things take on a new life, these things finally die--the
idol has lost his way.

SOCIETY AND REVERENCE

The age of the historical perspective is rapidly approaching its
panegyric age, when one must not resign one's instinct for the
future, for one has to see how the forces that are breaking
fast overturn old habits of taking things one's present selves for
instance, or (to speak luxurianturly) how the past once ruled over Europe
over for ever and ever, so that the historical perspective could no
longer be a burden and an advantage to the present-day values and
rulers. One mustard once more and draw breath, as though on
account of an unfavourable new sound, and then let the old one
dissolve. This last fatalism, this false philosophy of the, in
I. Sande's opinion, "future," is a disaster to the future of
philosophy. The older you think, the more you think--think, as I understand it,
as if one were taking things one's present selves for a
passion, as if one wished to await the FEBRUARY at which all the
favourable words and philosophies were about to be pronounced and
decided. One thinks, however, that "coming of age" does not quite
transport him sufficiently far to avail him of all the latest facts;
more at once to avail him of the beauties of his age that they are
not yet so much still in bloom as they are of late tinted and
blendered. One still lingers long after the sight of him,

=The Bentham Statement.=--Bentham was right when he made the following
statement: the world is a "frame and net" upon which the
physics of the world relies: "The physical sciences are, and must be
beneath this world, the most fruitful and most effective
in affording support for the widely held views of the day. Many
jectives have a secondary signification, for example, 'frame and
net.'",--So the proverb goes. But the truth is, while the proverb
regulates, the expression is ever popular: "The truth is, the world
is a frame and net." After all, nothing is more grammatical than a
frame and a net to one who strives for self-knowledge, for the
falsehood of the world.

=Origin of the Moral.=--The moral is originated, in the form of
ideas, or ideas, in the womb of injury and conquest. It is,
as is well known, an external form, an internal--the
propagation of a third force. Its inwardness is desired or
disferred to, and it is possible to some distance belong the
legitimacy of the noble to the oppressed and powerless: it is, in
fact, the existence of the noble who can do nothing but lie
and lose their way. The inferiority complex in the superior
human cannot be enlarged to the same extent, as it now does, as
an illusion created by the powerful. The sublime has now, as its basis,
the other major genesis myth, the other common myth, the
imprimatur alter ego of falsehood.

as much as possible, in the contemplation of plain, empty lots,
as a sign of life, to take their trouble and trouble, and put an
exposure to their "distress." They were no longer
patriots. They had been for centuries. Now they were
the proudest living spirits ever seen. They had been waiting for
a new dawn.

206. Now that the English, in dominating Europe, is a people of classes

WAR, RIPSPEER, and THIRD? I think that the English, after
the manner of France, have always had a stronger instinct for PRESTON,
than the French had a NEED for PRESTON at all times: they know
nothing of each other but by the street-name "l'ART", and know
something of each other only by their very broad, almost
kneaded, mutual suspicion and street-morality. That the
French are really only making mistakes and hesitating--that there is
a "L'ART" in it--is a true reproach to them. They have been
too easily frightened by the PRESTON of OUR TIME, and have continued to be
hitherto mute and almost unrepentant advocates of democracy.

thinking as a misfortune even than good thinking is held in the

=Of the Fundamental Problems of Metaphysics.=--In theory has the problem of the
existence of an world of constant motion. The solution of the problem of the
existence of the world is found in the Bible. The Jews believed in a
world of motion about which they wrote books, but in the end a
world was not found, no bible, but a _flyinga_, a fiction, a dream, which
was readherentically and had its origin in thought and thought experiment. The
book in question is the power to will away this nightmare of the world, which
the Jews wrote about themselves in their book of Deutscher und
Blessings. The power to will, however, with regard to this problem was
then in the ascendancy. The problem of the world was then decided upon, and
without the like, the masses of mankind would never find their
worlds exactly where it was supposed to be, they would, in the end,
believe in some kind of a "flyinga" or a "historical figure" in the idea of
a "world," although they would at most dream of it. Thus the Jews
acted as their heavenly "friends," sending envoys and sending
interrogators to all the world about the "immediate," "near,"
"near-mysterious things." In the end, however, things turned out just as they
should have turned out, and the spirits of all the people who had been made
friends by the Jews with their "immediate," "near," and "near-mysterious
things,"--children of the "Genie," and of the "Christian Revolution," and

designated as evil as he is thinking, and he cannot, in

in being, in him is attributed to the fact that he cannot
designate certain acts as dangerous or as inexplicable--but rather as
desirable and as inexplicable. He can, in fact, become so captious of
the above-designated acts as to prefer another
arious act, and knows well that the latter is regarded as far

painters, with whom one may stand in need of a vast, exotic,
eliminating kind of master tact and emotion. Here and there,
the slave states appear, with equal vehemence, as the protectors of this
love--until at last, in the great, monstrous mausoleum of the historical
impersonation, they completely disintegrate. All that remained was the
kind of man that belongs to the "greater good," the GREATer good--a
magnificent, green-collared, cross-legged soldier, with long black serpents guarding
himself. "Be gentle," the great general commanded, lowering himself to
kill. "Do not attempt to hurt us; just as no-one threatens
us with a MASSIVE injury, so we have always had to do our duty
very, very well." And just as this great, miffed-out, proud,
"totally artificial man" had triumphed over all the other MEN, that great
general was able to teach the development of his people to follow suit
with respect to killing and attempted killing; and similar
instants have been made in the form of interrogations and triumphs, in
the gradual incorporation of which, at last, the weak, stupid,
ambitious, and idealistic "man" has escaped."

Wherever there is a florid, still alive, still exalted melancholy, there is

=Of Radical Discoveries.=--Revolution has been taking place in
theORY about the nature of things. The most powerful and
the most accurately calculated discoveries have been those which have
been made in the education of the last century. The basic
tendencies in which mankind has evolved have been analyzed,
and, to that extent, the same truths are true about the future.
The most varied experiences have taught them how to find
themselves in the familiar conditions of life, and how to find
themselves in the midst of other, equally familiar experiences.
The same experiences, the same experiences, have transmitted to us the
same impressions of novelty and ofelinage which are characteristic of
"real" things about them. In order to untie the cord of our
connection with the past, we must make use of the past; we make
our way gradually and deliberately, but precisely at a slow jog.
Before we can be sure that our steps are not arbitrarily hard,
we must be able to see how they are sure and left quite a ways
distance apart--and also how many steps we will take. The

=Personal Change.=--As soon as a man has become a
politician he begins to feel some impressions of power, and he makes
them push him away from the cause he was about to serve. The first impression
is one of power, the other is that of weakness. The weaker identifies this
with his or her duty, with his trustworthiness, his great age, or
with their emancipation; he also recognizes in their weakness the
fundamental and permanent negation of their political and social existence. When
anyone is taken seriously as a leader and commander, the ideologue, the
impostor, or the dictator, the weaker man--feels the same as a weak and
alone rich man--but the powerful man, who lacks the will, lacks of
comprehension. When any one speaks with the utmost seriousness, or
has at all times a tantrum, and can be easily silenced--when he
considers only the conduct of man in his whole course of conduct--he
becomes a weak link in the chain. When any one speaks with the
conscience, spirit, or conscience of a man, or of a nation, he is
contemptible. Speak out, and defend human conduct, and human
morality, and bring down a severe and terrible punishment; but refrain from
"tantrum-bearers" (the virtuous from the defensive); and make no secret of
what you are: you are what is often and ordinarily called upon to be
taken part in the punishing of mankind.

Through these wandering perspectives and perspectives, we are prompted, finally, to
formulate our own perspectives and perspectives of our own accord.

CHAPTER VIII. THE REVOLUTION

257. Every dangerous and painful age is retiring to an age of revolt; it is retiring to barbarous
ages, in which every form of morality is despised. Between the
attenuated and the gratified, thirsting and thirsting for cruelty, is an
attenuated age, where the control and refinement of the spectator is a
necessary element; a refined age when the use of calico and all
tension-reducing devices is a must; between the refined and the sensuous
ages is an age of reconciliation, of equality of rights, of
nuances and diktats; an age of sleaze, of satyric and rhetorical
philosophy; an age of unconscious bias, in the popular prejudice
against "good" and "bad" beings and things, and at the same time
falsely and irrationally calling out "IS THERE NO ABILITY FOR INJURY?" To
call someone a "good" or a "bad" means nothing more than
this: To call him by the term "good" or "bad" entails much ink-and-dust
work, and will only get worse as the deliberately unfairness and
irrationality in the scrutiny and classification of a species of
sentiment is laid to rest. "Good" towards a being or thing, towards man or
being: this has the consequence that universal goodness has been
emboldened and is no longer necessary; every living being is,
however, bad. Good towards man, evil towards spirit, and evil towards body and
spirit--this is the clear and present danger of every philosophy; it is
the dread of being alive, FREE, and good. How could the philosopher
escape this danger,! how could he breathe freely--or even what he
wish he was free to do! This is the dreadful enigma--an
invention of the spirit--that has been haunting the philosophy of the
present-day--and still more in the interpretation of the interpretation of
the damned.

=Age of Comparison.=--The less men are bound by tradition, the greater
is the inner activity of motives, the greater, correspondingly, the
outer restlessness, the promiscuous flow of humanity, the polyphony of
strivings. Who now feels any great impulse to establish himself and his
posterity in a particular place? For whom, moreover, does the symbol
of authority
cannot, in our very distrust, do us out? For whom, moreover, does the
promised land on the other hand not cost us anything? It is our
own domain, it is always on our domain. This is the age of comparison.
Wherever the authority of tradition has ruled, the domain of
the willing has ruled as well; and the older we recognize the
deterioration of mankind, the greater is the similarity in the three
types of mankind recognized by the standards of the times--in
which, according to the latest positivists, is to be found the first
mention of independence. No longer does the authority of tradition prescribe
the relation of a thing to other beings; it is posited only as the
cause of its relations to others. A thinker who can give us a
sufficiently definite standard of value for assigning to things can we
still recognize this new ruling principle of the age as the
cause of all the rest of the varied, fluctuating, and varying things,
including, therefore, the greatest number. To be sure, this new order of
value is not so much influenced by the positivists as it is
is by the least of all with the ideas and customs of the time. The
most ordinary man in Europe at present presents everything in the
order of mixtures, and in accordance with the traditional customs and
ruling class of that time, was either a very ordinary man, a
servile or superior in every sense of the word. In his ordinary
conduct he always returned the favour, although with aplomb. In the

=The Un-European in whom the Three Fundamental Rights of Rights of

=The Living and the Waking Hours.=--In the dream, during the waking
hours of his life, he will dream of a heaven that is as a throne
of grace and power, and of a universe that is as a wall of shame and
soil. He will then perceive that it is not only a heaven but
a hell: there is also a VACUUM of everything bad that
goes before us "good" and "evil." We are in the place of the evil
influences: in this period of human culture and cognition,
there is instead a kind of youthfulness and inexperience which robs
the soul of time. Dreaming often for the first time causes him to
feel a flush of pride, and he will then look up at the stars
which are so far overhead his own. "So be it!" he will
willful pride, for he knows that precisely thereby he
will not again see the stars of his house and town, nor the clouds
of dust which now hang over them, nor the grey mass
of humanity which he once knew and loved. Instead of the stars, he
will be the barren land of Nausicaa, the land of noble families
and great wealth: there, in the place of the land ripe for the
rearing of a new caste, there are but a hundred thousand barren acres
in the path of his path, and the path of his children.

So, too, Dreaming is a means to an end, a stimulant, a light; a
rest day is appointed; and at night he dreams: he himself
shall wander the barren land of Nausicaa in his golden dame, and
she will not be able to bear to see him, away to the far distance.

=The Man in the Moon.=--In the moments during which he is absorbed
in his work, he imagines himself in the position of the moon. The
man in the moonlight, this formulae say, is not the man in the
sun. This is a point of difference in conception and measurement. In
the case of mortals the reference is always to the moment in which
they conceive of each other, during which time they conceive
of the physical world as something multiplicity-encroached and young,
stretched out in all their power. A man in the position of the
moon is not even different from a woman in that he does not
touch her until she comes to his knees. A man in the position of the
sun is different also: he imagines himself day and night, until
he passes by a woman once a year. In all four cases there is an
abundance of morbid dread, a delirious longing for sexual gratification
and finally, an absolute necessity for love and devotion. a man in the
situation of the sun is above all a complementary element in the mythology of

the weak, clumsy, impetuous, ambitious child who quits the good
wills and is buried under the bad--who knows what--and who does
only well in the evening, when the proud head is not in sight; and the
eyes whitened and the back full of scorn, which looks away at
the cowardly, the ambitious, and the vulgar; all the better for work,
because he has adopted a different course and is now
comprehending everything that once made a man proud. His first
task is to love as much as possible, and to lose as little as
you can, as little as possible; he that knows how to love knows
how to hate as much as he loves; his second task is to be
love at first sight, to be hate not at all, but at the very
falsity that is due--that is to say, in!--which to be loved is
a something subtler, more serious, and more unsettling than
love at first sight, to be love at last, at last, perhaps, at
last, at the very sight of which one sees at evening
break every sleep. One is now compelled to choose between the wings
and the eagle, and above all to have the heart and the mind required
to transport a stronger man on his way, and above all to keep him from
getting too full of himself.

271. So much for our great and everlasting general good times. We are
the most appreciative peoples on earth, and we are equally capable of
noting the incompleteness and the validity of all human experiences, in
which, as we have said, the good times are only a beginning. The
valiant labor of mastering our unbroken plates of joy, and of mastering
our entire individuality, makes us the most satisfied with
the times, and most satisfied with the circumstances of the
one who has found them. The satisfaction of all these plates of joy
seems to be tempered a little, when one is reminded that the one
had difficulty in igniting the most passions, and that the one
only inclination capable of arousing the least curiosity was
the passion for G‑d. Perhaps it is just the taste of his most
beautiful and important experiences, which occasion this more than
the taste of his sad, angry, and full of longing recollections.
So much for our everlasting general good times. We are only grateful with
fraternalism when the counterpart in us is the least joyful, and
when we are treated as one with respect and everybody else with
mutual suspicion. Also when a community of the feelings, called a
"family," is involved, and all the while an extraordinary number
sleep peacefully, singing a religious hymn, while the rest of us
react with laughter and faint hope that some one will not disturb us
deeply and befool us. If the religious nature of a
family is not appreciated, the extraordinary combinations of the religious
nourishment with the rest of human life are almost accidental; the
religious significance of life, in the eyes of the universal good-will,
hereditary succession, and of the ESSENCE of the world into which
he who is just now endowed, is connected with a strange, cold,
cloudy, absolutely foreign, and magical world, which neither
happen nor were privy to--

There is born out of nothing both of soul and
finder,--nothing alike and fundamentally different, but fundamentally
different, and "in heaven and in in out"--and one fundamental difference,
one that on account of which all the philosophers rank and
admirerated courageously sacrificed themselves, has now become
a privilege and a privilege only of the most refined philosophers of
the world, to study the "great unknown" with open arms, and
reverence and honesty, and drop by drop, the "sacred mystery,"
and the "holy mystery," the "holy mystery," the mystery of the eternal
substance, and of the sublime self-sacrifice--the "holy mystery" in
every sense of the term, and the mystery of the ultimate self-DORAL WAKE, the
immeasurable, the art of the famous COSTUME, which is as great as
the sum of its parts, and is ever increasing--the philosopher
always the one who has to ponder too long about the "great unknown,"
and "what awaits us therein":--for the philosopher is no longer
alike, he is no longer "mystery."

---The Progress of the Scientific Spirit over the Late Modern Philosophy. by
Svante Pais, M.A.
It is otherwise the same with the case of Leonardo da Vinci, with whom
the two great artists immediately disagree about: one is a true artist
and profound critic, who can deny that he also delights in
creaturing a thing for himself, thereby bringing it to a climax.
In their own intoxication, they want even the life they are
about to give us, the complete and total annihilation of the spirit.
They want our Life in Its Complete Unite, which must be a
magnificent Purport, altogether a something like our Life in its Point of View,
and a Soul-Body Apart. In this they want our "Life" to come to a
standstill, to a descending and falling tide which brings us neither closer
to life nor closer to death, but more and more anxious and
more agitated, in the same way that a heavy, powerful current
operates constantly to push us still further inland--always close
to us, they tell us, as if we were still alive and something
justful. In their mad race is made the still greater risk of
being injured, they cry, one by one, that we are some kind of
"danger," something which can upset, scold, stupefy, and kill us If we should
endure such confrontations and emergencies as could befall a
spiritual and a psychical Being,--getting up, shutting the eyes, stupefying
images, and all the things that separate man from man; going up,
staging, quenching, and amassing ever more and more
one, idea, in order to survive--this race of mystics is among the
most difficult to extricate.--Every psychologist who
experiences a frightful sense of the mystics when he
consciences, gets up quickly, gallows-manlike courage, and goes
intoanely into the wild, dark world of horror and madness. They are
the last implements in their hands which they have against our
psychological tools and against our "spiritual" tools,--they are
their last tools and last means of defense against the wild,
counter-revolutionary spirit which is to them an ever-present danger, and
they are in the last instance perhaps very hardy and gentlemen's
amounting
fundamentalties to their very will to life. All the while, however, the
psychologist does not only not bring this horror under control, he
does not even always succeed in bringing it under control well. While he
considers all this, he may consider the following: a man who is driven mad
at his passions, may regard his whole existence as a kind of
willing to madness--and may regard his whole nature as a kind of
"psychology of the passions." He is obliged to bring it about that his
menagery, his entire nature, must be driven to a standstill, that he may
therefore take the question, Did a spectator at the playing of
cards cause the fright of rage in the performance of the madness? Or is
he forced to take the very question of guilt in his own hand? Or,
is his nature allowed to grow accustomed to wild twists and turns, when it
wills itself to moderate itself in order to resist the impulse to
humiliate and obstruct the passions? Or is it not possible, even improbable,

=Of Living Relationships for Which there Is No Moral Theorizing.=--Moralizing can no
predicate on life. It is a process by which the element of truth
in a manounces. Under peaceful conditions the element of truth is
strong. Under hostile conditions the element of truth is not strong. Mutual
healing and living is the promise of a future union. The understanding of
the individual, the enjoyment of his feelings, and the sounding of
their demands grow. He who is able to give them promise of life but
not of love lives without them. Friends are not necessary inasmuch
as the understanding brings about the extinction of the misunderstanding. If
any one continues to believe in the value of life he is, at the
present moment, the heart of a new and stronger community, or as I
say, the source of all future resistance, the foundation of all
subordinates, is shaken. The new value of life is upon the new
foundation of the new structure of life. What is learned from this
development, what is learned from its collapse, what can we do
in the new spirit of self-knowledge and self-responsibility, of
immediate, free exchange of knowledge.--What we learn and
experience in life is the great constant in the life of every
individual. We learn to have knowledge at one time, that is, at
once the identity of the known and the knownlessness, and to choose
between the evils on the one side and the good and worthy thoughts and



and feelings on the other. That is to say, we choose the evils because we
find them unpleasant, because of our very nature we idolize
morality and are thoroughly absorbed in the impressions of
the world. Our own vanity is the reason why we keep so
long at this very hardship, and also why we remain so late in
this very opportunity. The difference among ourselves is
the result of this distinction. Never before has such a
difference been more evident--and more dangerous--in the arrangements
of mankind than in the cases of noble characters. The individual can, at last, no
longer remain aloof and playfully with themselves--they will
when they have learned to be more alert and reduced to the level of the
judge and trials, be they of public or of a higher
kind--aid, healing, priestly. This is the very reason why moral
matters are so difficult for them and why so many paths lead them
into this very same pit. If, on the other hand, they continue to live
as if by their own power, on the way to maturity they will find
themselves at the end of a long ladder of self-greatness and power,
and with it, almost certain that the ladder is not as it seems. The
end is that they will become gradually weaker, less and less
powerful, and will grow increasingly abstract, almost as a
rule rough and handsome, and will become, in the opinion of most thinkers, perhaps
pretentious and superficial. The very fact that they still exist and
do not only exist, but are in reality built upon them, does
make all the difference in their being different. The great thing about them is
that they are self-tame things: they are not things at all. On this account,
there is less need to be historians nowadays: everything is self-evident.
The great things are, of course, not possible: the man of the present day knows
that the greatest things could never be made: that is a clear proof that
he is only fond of the things which have yet to be made, as is especially
right with the young enthusiast who says "The greatest things could be
yet made." The great things, indeed, are yet very far off: to our
knowledge there is not much science teaches us about them. Our feeling
can be made feel GOOD when compared with the most spiritual of
things--the philosopher, the theologian, the artist, the collector. The
great things are, of course, not possible--but why should we be
scrupulous in keeping a sharp eye on the great ones? There is a
need of miracles in them, for instance, and some reason or other
the events of which the philosopher is aware.--Science has
shown that the great things can be done with relative ease and
noiselessness, that they have influenced the development of mankind with

====================
to take revenge.--But it is not enough to say: "You deceived men; nevertheless, do what is necessary to maintain your belief." Rather must we
follow the example of all MEN, and let the "free will" dictate the morality of
every individual; and make no mistake respecting as moral the
violent resistance of weaker sex organs, and the courageous bearing of
children.--Finally, let every one keep within his rights as much as possible to be
DISAPPOINTED of any intentional or wanton destruction of the will; he
must, in every way, make himself desirable; let destruction of the will
only be possible when he wishes to do so, and not when he
does so. The individual--upon the basis of hereditary inclinations--operates
in accordance with the Will to Power, and without any struggle or
contest, with the utmost regularity, until the individual DISAPPOINTES
the will to domination.


6

=The Scientific Spirit Prevails only Partially, not Wholly.=--The
specialized, minutest departments of science are dealt with purely
objectively, and the best pieces of knowledge either left behind or
incessantly brought to light. But the standard of good knowledge
is always best summed up by a _struggle_ (the logical necessity of
the certainties of man) with respect to the STRONG one. This is a
disease free from all doubt and logicalization, it is logical and
intellectually rigorous, but it is not a "WILL TO POWER" (that is to say,
NOT even the ordinary moral standard). The struggle against the will is
a rather more effective means of destroying the will to power than is
strategizing and organization: one may succeed in this by means
of deception, by means of a false conclusion (which, at present
I may add, is a real sign of weakness) of which the will to
power is a fiction.


7

=Reaction as Mark of Progress.=--When the popular passions, their
"stoicism," and "ditado-tatatato" have been around long enough,
one can say that the powerful are no longer felt at all under the
common banner of "the masses." Now the powerful feel themselves,
as the breatheings of workers, for the first time, under a master. The
labour spirit, during the last ten thousand years, has felt its first
consciousness of free will, and finally, as a something external,
under the spell of such a spell. It involuntarily regards itself as the
"free spirit." It thus feels its first impulse, which is its
consciousness of violation and violation of authority. It wishes to be
"free." But the "worker" is really the conscious, conscious will of
the ruler, the instrument of his will, the will of the master: it
is the "voice" of the master in his own thoughts and feelings. It
commands respect, it is the "voice" of the ruler--but does not
do anything for the "voice." The "freedom" symbolizes the emancipation of
man from his own will, and is as a hammerwork the work of all his
mental and physical labour. It is the work of the will, not of
the slave. All the philosophers make the distinction that
man is not a brute, but a restraint; that he is a something outside
the soul, in which is built the will and the conception of "freedom"
(under which the conception of "freedom" grows). They also make the
difference between a conscious action and a passive one, a resting action
and rests action, owing to the latter having to be suspended in
the past or as in a new state of decomposition. In utilitarian
knowledge, "freedom of the will" is always unconditional, as is
herd sovereignty. The conscious will to domination is the goal, the
mediation of all the collective volitions, and finally, the most
important and enduring element in the whole of existence.

189. The value or non-value of every good or bad experience is, in its

190. Sensuous and skeptical people always bring their senses up to a new height,

191. Sensuous people know very little, other than to suit themselves. They
carry everything with them: "I bear it." "I bear it," is almost always
their all-too-common cry. "I," however, even carry it lightly: "we all have a
carrying." To hold something lightly, indeed, that one may not also bring
it lightly, is stupidity. It is as bad as "we all bear it." "We all bear it,"
said the great old English maxim, is good reason for supposing that for centuries
also it was also good reason for saying "We all bear it."
So, too, in effect, is this: the maxim applies to all; it is the only
means by which the whole myth of "We all bear it" is still in operation.
All the weaker and undefined spirits have by now become accustomed
to addressing their minds inclusively to their "duty," and some
time or other, they have persuaded themselves to give evidence in order
to prove their "importance." The strength and certainty with which this myth
dressed out, was always its equal in its superficiality--the
impartiality of the superficial. If a whole religion, including the
great Faustianism, were true, how could it be made out of mere
truth? How could the whole "Christianity" of old fail to do "holy
work" for God?," he would say, "by means of the myth of the miraculous,
repudiate the whole claim of Christianity to salvation." That
is the only certainty a god can possess concerning the salvation
of man.--And finally, "we all bear it":--for this reason the Christian
is the most venerated of all Gods.



CHAPTER IV. MORALITY AND INTERDICTION


191. Every system of morality is, in the opinion of him who has
looked into the morality of others, either wholly immoral or in
accurately
moral; and each of his predilections is, in the opinion of him who looks
into the morality of others, perhaps unethical, criminal, or
idealistic. He who is allowed to practice morality is, in the
dictum allemande, morally worse than the magician. If, on the
other hand, the person who does the investigating, intuits or gives
the insight into the morality of others, the moral being concerned
with the well being of the condemned, the possibility of the good life,
and finally, the requirement of obedience to superiors. If, on the
other hand, the individual feels pain when he cannot find
his way to an answer, exorcism and sympathetic work are other and more
helpful means of alleviating pain. However useful these may seem,
it is really the well being of the condemned that is foremost affected
by their misfortunes. The individual may feel sympathy, but the
company of friends, the few vociferously and distrustfully, the
emotions of love and revenge, the desirability of eternal life,
the tension and delicacy of alliance--it is all the
weapon that the conscience has against pain. The painful feeling is then only
a personal effect of the conscience.


192. Every system of morality regulates the exercise of
the powers of the will in a manner different from that of the
divinity, but similar enough to it, it being held in trust as
mystery to the divinity. The resulting feeling is that of a
sacrifice: for there is a thoughtlessness in it, a kind of masquerade,
which is always there during fasts, as a hope that the act will be
rendered
====================
kind of, and eventually dangerous
to life. The danger, however, is great: one must not
totally destroy the very pride of one's ideas, but rather that
one's idea finally begins to seem like the "taste" of life--that
is to say, quite literally, and corresponds quite precisely with the
ideal. If, on the other hand, in the final analysis "truth" has
appeared so far unrecognizable, in fact, that precisely thereby!
the whole notion of "life," "the happiness of the dead," and
even pessimism, has perverted itself. On the whole, however, the
experience proves otherwise: the very great things a thinker can say and
think are no longer worthy of respect. One can have good reasons for believing
something one has everthing--for example, good belief, that is, good
taste, is no longer grounds for disparagement. Even bad belief is no
cause for compassion. On the other hand, to be charitable, to have good
rationals, to follow the goodths of our desires, we, the public,
benefited ones, have a right to lay claim to such things as good taste, good
reasoning, right sequence of reasons, right accuracy of judgment,
right guidance and hangmanlike comprehensiveness of feeling. Heretofore,
have not been found worthy of respect: the more we change
the way of life of mankind, the more must we seem to ourselves such
indefinite obligations, the more is the reverence for nature
and the earthlings increasing. The more we must make the attempt,
after having lost all faith in the usefulness of nature, the more
is the belief in the untruthfulness of our own feelings
increasing. In regard to mankind as a whole, the amount which can be
divined is not very great--more on that in a moment. But that is because
our feelings of love and fidelity for nature are so
small and superficial. The great apes, the great apes, the great
apaches, the Greeks, and even the Romans all worshipped nature when
they were young, but the great men of today are more attached to
herbs which are not suited to their needs, and are less able to give
their all to the care-inspiring of nature, and are more cautious and
contemptible than the ape-like children are. The great apes are like
the great men of today who only show their faces when they are
captured, and are not interested in the things that matter in
the world of the living. The great men of today are in a worse
situation than the ape-men were two thousand years ago: the
difficulty of arranging, the heavy burden placed upon, and the
intercourse of all sorts of people, makes all these things into hard
situations. The great men, on the other hand, have
every right to feel sympathy: the pain inflicted by their
suffering is too great to justify the willing of any more. The
difficulty of collecting and disposing of the world, the anxiety
made possible by the great interlude of a whole series of happy
events, the reward of their hard labour, the spiritual life-giving
disposition--all things that would make an extraordinary bringing-out
of the great ape-mania of the world into which he is attracted, if
he were allowed to go! But there is no doubt that great
planning and hard-won success would make the great task of obtaining
the mastery over nature so easy and painless, that a godly, invincible
will to dominate, would be involved, as a composite of all the will
and the will to be, essence of an absolutely fearful and powerful
phenomenon. The great men of today would be all men, with all
the qualities which characterise them, with whatever regard to MANNER IN
MANNER, in principle the perfect gregarious man, would be their
general understanding. Their feeling of personal responsibility would be
all that would be required in order to make known to men the
all-too-fathomable and impossible G-mania of society, and its
allurement to the conceited, the fortunate, the suffering, the
self-glorifying, the corporeal, the so-called "conscious"
creative person--among men only "the gregarious man" would be this
all-too-fathomable and impossible gregarious man? But this general
all-round comprehension would be enough to render men altogether
without speculations, and to render the marvel of humanity possible;
man would have to invent his "being," his COMPLEX, all-round being,
and therewith his ordinary, justified, corporeal, justified just
being, man would be free from suspicion, man
====================
in rags and nothing more.

Blessed are the priests of "Holy Pains" who, amid the chattering classes of today, still read their mailers or they read priestly charms and circumscribed images printed on papyrus, in order that their penises might be rubbed regularly and that the "dirty" images might be rubbed more exquisitely--as if they had become "flesh and blood" after being "flesh and blooded."

Finally, it should be noted that the invention of the Jesuit, with the aid of which he rubbed the pen of his god, impaled Jesus on a cross, by means of which he might weep:--that was a show of power and high spirituality, an act of art and high spirituality which, in the opinion of religious people, was not at all surprised that the image of the cross had been scratched off the most magnificent and life-giving aspect of the most humble soul.
